applicability_reasoning: This regulation does not apply to the provided pension scheme rules document for several reasons: 1) The document is a set of scheme rules for a company pension life cover product and does not contain any advertisements or marketing materials. 2) While the document describes benefits and terms of the pension scheme, it does not make any guarantees or use terms conveying guarantee impressions that would trigger regulation 390. 3) The document is primarily focused on defining the legal and operational framework of the pension scheme, including definitions, trustee duties, scheme benefits, and administrative procedures. The only mentions of 'guarantee' in the document are in section 4.5 regarding trustee powers to give guarantees in an administrative context, not in relation to product marketing or consumer communications. The regulation specifically targets how investment products are advertised and described to consumers, which is not the purpose or content of this document.
regulation_title: Conditions for describing product as guaranteed or conveying the same meaning or impression 20 [81]
regulation_text: 390. A regulated entity shall ensure that an advertisement does not describe an investment product as guaranteed, either fully or partially, or by using descriptive terms that convey such a meaning or impression, unless - (a) there is a legally enforceable guarantee agreement in place in which a guarantor undertakes to meet, to whatever extent is stated in the advertisement, a consumer's claim under the guarantee, (b) the regulated entity has made, and can demonstrate that it has made, an assessment of the amount of the guarantee, (c) it clearly states the nature and extent of limitations of the guarantee and the name of the guarantor, and (d) the advertisement states that the guarantee is provided by a connected party of the regulated entity, if applicable.
source_name: CENTRAL BANK (SUPERVISION AND ENFORCEMENT) ACT 2013 (SECTION 48) (CONSUMER PROTECTION) REGULATIONS 2025
